description: Fundamental course in organic chemistry based upon the modern concepts of structure and mechanism of reactions.
name: ORGANIC CHEMISTRY I

values.comments:
Chemistry 241 discusses fundamental concepts in Organic Chemistry, based on concepts of structures and reaction mechanisms.

Students’ feedback for the course was overwhelmingly positive. Several students commented that it was a "wonderful organic chemistry experience" and one of the "most interesting" courses at Penn.   

Professor Molander's reviews were similarly ecstatic. Students thought he presented the difficult course material in “a very accessible manner.” What set Professor Molander apart from other professors of the same course was his accessibility. As one student wrote, he had an almost constant “availability to discuss questions and concerns.” Students could tell that Professor Molander “cares deeply about his students.”

As expected for an Organic Chemistry course, students thought the class was difficult. Students found that the class required "independent reading and mastery," and thought that the tests were "difficult, but fair."

Chemistry 241 discusses fundamental concepts in Organic Chemistry, based on concepts of structures and reaction mechanisms.

Students’ major complaint about the content of the class had to do with the lack of assigned practice problems from the textbook to guide their studying. Several reported that the Professor did not direct their reading nor assign specific practice problems. Another complaint was that the administration of the course was disorganized. Students complained about practice exams posted on Blackboard that were “missing pages or answer keys” as well as a lack of communication between the teacher and the TAs.

Several students praised Professor Bode’s “straightforward manner” in communicating the course material, one student even describing him as “one of the best lecturers at Penn.” However, Professor Bode’s lack of accessibility was a major concern. Students reported that Professor Bode “missed more classes than nearly all of his students” and “never responded to e-mail.” They found his one hour a week office hours insufficient, and expressed dismay at his perceived lack of interest in teaching.

The difficult material covered in this course required significant time commitment and hard work. The quizzes of this class were "tough to keep up with," and some students complained that they commonly covered material that the Professor had previously stated would not be included. Most students found the exams to be difficult and intense.

Chemistry 241 discusses fundamental concepts in Organic Chemistry, based on concepts of structures and reaction mechanisms.

Students overall found the material presented in this class to be highly worthwhile. Many commented that the course was interesting, and felt that their problem-solving skills were enhanced despite the importance of memorization.

Students overwhelmingly enjoyed Professor Winkler's "engaging and hilarious" lectures, praising his ability to "communicate the wonders" of organic chemistry in a "clear, logical manner.” Several students commented on the Professor’s “high expectations” for their performance in the course; while some appreciated his “effort to ensure that all students learned the material” and felt challenged, others felt he was not understanding enough when it came to students struggling with the difficulty of the material. Winkler was highly accessible, holding “over five office hours per week.”

Students found that mastering the material required "immense amounts of work," and spent a lot of time doing as many problems as possible to prepare for the four midterms.

Chemistry 241 discusses fundamental concepts in Organic Chemistry, based on concepts of structures and reaction mechanisms.

Some students found the material presented in this class enjoyable, but most were deterred due to the course’s difficulty.

While there were one or two positive reviews for Professor Walsh, and students did agree that he was an effective and knowledgeable lecturer, the overwhelming opinion of students who took this class was that Professor Walsh created a “hostile atmosphere” by belittling medical professionals and making “condescending” comments towards students who struggled with the material. They felt that the Professor made it clear he did not want to be teaching the class, and felt that he was not very accessible. Students also complained that his use of the PowerPoint slides that came with the online registration of the textbook was not effective in conveying the material.

Most of the students in this course were LPS students studying to go to medical school, and would not recommend taking this course with Professor Walsh. Many would have preferred assigned problems for the textbook instead of being instructed to “do every problem in the book,” which they felt was unreasonable, especially for students who were balancing the class with full time jobs. Students also disliked that the exams did not reflect the manner in which material was presented in class, causing some to do poorly.
